Exploring Age-of-Information Weighting in Federated Learning under Data Heterogeneity

Kaidi Wang,  Zhiguo Ding,  Daniel K. C. So,  and Zhi Ding Kaidi Wang and Daniel K. C. So are with the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, The University of Manchester, Manchester, M13 9PL, UK (email: kaidi.wang@ieee.org, d.so@manchester.ac.uk).Zhiguo Ding is with Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Khalifa University, Abu Dhabi, UAE, and Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Manchester, Manchester, UK (email: zhiguo.ding@manchester.ac.uk).Zhi Ding is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616 USA (email: zding@ucdavis.edu).
Abstract

This paper investigates federated learning in a wireless communication system, where random device selection is employed with non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data. The analysis indicates that while training deep learning networks using federated stochastic gradient descent (FedSGD) on non-IID datasets, device selection can generate gradient errors that accumulate, leading to potential weight divergence. To mitigate training divergence, we design an age-weighted FedSGD to scale local gradients according to the previous state of devices. To further improve learning performance by increasing device participation under the maximum time consumption constraint, we formulate an energy consumption minimization problem by including resource allocation and sub-channel assignment. By transforming the resource allocation problem into convex and utilizing KKT conditions, we derived the optimal resource allocation solution. Moreover, this paper develops a matching based algorithm to generate the enhanced sub-channel assignment. Simulation results indicate that i) age-weighted FedSGD is able to outperform conventional FedSGD in terms of convergence rate and achievable accuracy, and ii) the proposed resource allocation and sub-channel assignment strategies can significantly reduce energy consumption and improve learning performance by increasing the number of selected devices.

Index Terms:
Age-of-information (AoI), device selection, federated learning, resource allocation, sub-channel assignment

I Introduction

With the spread of computer chips, powerful computational capabilities become available at edge nodes, and therefore, the collected data can be directly utilized for learning tasks [1]. In this context, federated learning, as a promising technology for distributed learning, has attracted considerable attention from both academia and industry. In federated learning, a neural network is constructed by a central server and shared among all participating devices [2]. At each device, the received neural network is trained with local data and transmitted to the server for aggregation [3]. Compared with centralized learning that requires offloading raw data to the server, in federated learning, learning tasks are executed collaboratively without data sharing, and hence, privacy security can be improved [4]. Furthermore, since the size of the transmitted neural network is generally smaller than the size of original data, communication efficiency can be achieved [5]. However, since federated learning relies on periodic transmission, its performance is affected by wireless networks, and hence, the optimization of communications is recognized as an important research direction [6].

Due to the fact that federated learning usually involves a large number of devices for multiple rounds of training and transmission, device selection/sampling becomes a common method to implement this algorithm under limited bandwidth resources [7, 8]. Some existing works focused on addressing system heterogeneity by selecting devices based on hardware specifications and communication environment [9, 10, 11, 12]. In [9], device selection and beamforming design were jointly considered in an over-the-air computation (AirComp) based federated learning framework, where an optimization problem was formulated to maximize the number of selected devices. By revealing the interaction between global loss and packet error rates, device selection was included to cope with the limited number of resource blocks [10]. Particularly, in this work, a device can be selected only if the latency and energy consumption constraints can be satisfied. Since the transmitted models can be severely damaged by noise in AirComp based federated learning, in [11], devices with weak channel conditions were ignored for aggregation as the transmit power is not sufficient to compensate for the effects of wireless communications. Recognizing the degradation of learning performance caused by low device availability, the authors of [12] proposed a device selection strategy based on achievable long-term participation rates to mitigate the impact of device selection variance on global model convergence.

In realistic scenarios of federated learning, non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data is unevenly distributed among devices, which brings challenges to device selection [13, 14]. Specifically, in system based device selection, the server tends to select devices with better channel conditions and/or powerful computational capacities, which may lead to a decline in learning performance on non-IID datasets [15]. To this end, by selecting devices that provide more contributions in the aggregation, some works jointly considered system heterogeneity and data heterogeneity [16, 17, 18, 19]. In [16], channel conditions and local model updates were studied, and four device selection polices were proposed based on different priorities. Simulation results demonstrated that jointly including both metrics can provide better learning performance than using either metric separately. In order to achieve the target global loss within less time consumption, the selection probabilities of devices in the classic random device selection scheme were optimized based on latency and gradient norms [17]. Considering that the device contribution is not only related to dataset size, a biased device selection scheme was developed in [18], in which the server transmits the global model to a set of candidate devices for evaluation, and then selects devices with larger local losses. In [19], age-of-information (AoI) was considered as a metric to improve the fairness of device selection. It was indicated that by minimizing the overall AoI of all devices, both learning performance and time consumption can be improved.

Since learning based device selection is performed on a set of available devices, its performance can be further improved by increasing device availability, which is determined by channel conditions, computational capacities, battery levels, etc. [20, 12]. Therefore, it is necessary to explore the optimal resource allocation based on these factors. Energy consumption, as an important criterion that can directly limit device participation, has been extensively researched in existing works [21, 22, 23, 24, 25]. In [21], a comprehensive energy consumption minimization problem was investigated in federated learning systems, where monotonicity analysis was utilized to obtain solutions. Wireless federated learning was also studied in eavesdropping scenarios, in which idle devices transmit jamming signals to improve the secrecy rate of the transmitting device [22]. In[23], energy harvesting and non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) were exploited to provide computing energy and facilitate uplink transmission, respectively. In these works, the bisection method was utilized for algorithm design [21, 22, 23]. The authors of [24] focused on studying long-term energy consumption minimization, where deep reinforcement learning was employed. In [25], NOMA schemes were adopted in a clustered federated learning system, where sub-channel assignment and power allocation were studied to further enhance device availability.

As aforementioned, with non-IID data, system based device selection leads to a decline in learning performance [9, 10, 11, 12], while learning based device selection requires additional transmission and analysis for local models or gradients [16, 17, 18]. A novel method, namely age-weighted FedSGD, is proposed to mitigate the learning performance degradation caused by implementing device selection on non-IID datasets. This scheme can be employed in a variety of existing device selection strategies without extra information transmission and model/data analysis, and hence, it will not increase system overhead or cause privacy leakage. Compared to [19] which exploits AoI to guide device selection, in this work, the number of idle communication rounds serves as a weighting factor to directly regulate the update of global models. Moreover, to further increase device availability, an energy consumption minimization problem is jointly addressed through a low-complexity solution, thus avoiding the loss of optimality in previous works [21, 22, 23]. The main contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • •

    A wireless federated learning network with random device selection is investigated. It is proved that in conventional federated stochastic gradient descent (FedSGD), device selection with non-IID data results in an error in global gradients, which is accumulated and amplified during training, thereby increasing weight divergence.

  • •

    Based on the analyzed result, AoI is introduced to design age-weighted FedSGD, which can adjust the proportion of local gradients from selected devices in the global gradient. It is indicated that the proposed scheme enables the data distribution of the selected devices to approximate the global data distribution, thereby effectively reducing weight divergence.

  • •

    In order to further improve the performance of device selection, an energy consumption minimization problem is formulated to increase device availability. By decoupling the formulated problem into two sub-problems, KKT conditions and matching theory are utilized to develop the closed-form resource allocation solution and sub-channel assignment algorithm, respectively.

  • •

    Simulation results show that the proposed age-weighted FedSGD can significantly improve the performance of federated learning in the considered system, including convergence rate and achievable test accuracy. Moreover, KKT based resource allocation and matching based sub-channel assignment are able to minimize energy consumption and increase the number of selected devices.

II System Model

Consider a wireless communication scenario for non-IID federated learning, where a server and N𝑁N devices collaborate to execute a learning task through K𝐾K sub-channels. All nodes are equipped with single-antennas. The collections of devices and sub-channels are represented by 𝒩={1,2,⋯,N}𝒩12⋯𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\cdots,N\} and 𝒦={1,2,⋯,K}𝒦12⋯𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,2,\cdots,K\}, respectively. It is assumed that the number of available sub-channels is less than the number of devices, and thus a subset of devices is randomly selected111Note that although this work considers classic random device selection, the proposed method can be utilized with multiple existing advanced device selection strategies. to participate in the aggregation in each communication round, denoted by 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t}, where |𝒮t|≤K<Nsubscript𝒮𝑡𝐾𝑁|\mathcal{S}_{t}|\leq K<N. In each round, the global model and the device selection decision are transmitted from the server to all devices, and then the selected devices train the received global model using all local samples, as shown in the following:

fn​(𝐰(t))=1βn​∑i=1βnℓ​(𝐰(t);𝒙n,i,yn,i),subscript𝑓𝑛superscript𝐰t1subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝛽𝑛ℓsuperscript𝐰tsubscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖f_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}})=\frac{1}{\beta_{n}}\sum_{i=1}^{\beta_{n}}\ell(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}};\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}), (1)

where βnsubscript𝛽𝑛\beta_{n} is the number of local samples at device n𝑛n, 𝐰(t)superscript𝐰t\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}} is the global model in round t𝑡t, (𝒙n,i,yn,i)subscript𝒙𝑛𝑖subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖(\boldsymbol{x}_{n,i},y_{n,i}) is the i𝑖i-th sample at device n𝑛n. Given the set of selected devices 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t}, the global loss can be expressed as follows:

F​(𝐰(t),𝒮t)=∑n∈𝒮tβn​fn​(𝐰(t))∑n∈𝒮tβn.𝐹superscript𝐰tsubscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛superscript𝐰tsubscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{S}_{t})=\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\beta_{n}f_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}})}{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\beta_{n}}. (2)

For aggregation, FedSGD is employed, where selected devices transmit local gradients to the server, and the global model is updated at the server, as follows:

𝐰(t+1)=𝐰(t)−λ​∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒮t),superscript𝐰t1superscript𝐰t𝜆∇𝐹superscript𝐰tsubscript𝒮𝑡\vspace{-2mm}\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t+1)}}=\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}}-\lambda\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{S}_{t}), (3)

where λ𝜆\lambda is the learning rate.

In this paper, the following assumptions are considered.

Assumption 1.

With respect to 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, ∇F​(𝐰,𝒩)∇𝐹𝐰𝒩\nabla F(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{N}) is L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous, i.e.,

‖∇F​(𝐰(t−1),𝒩)−∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒩)‖≤L​‖𝐰(t−1)−𝐰(t)‖.norm∇𝐹superscript𝐰t1𝒩∇𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩𝐿normsuperscript𝐰t1superscript𝐰t\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t-1)}},\mathcal{N})\!-\!\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N})\|\leq L\|\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t-1)}}\!-\!\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\|. (4)
Assumption 2.

The global loss function F​(𝐰(t),𝒩)𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N}) satisfies the Polyak-Lojasiewicz inequality with positive parameter μ𝜇\mu, as shown in follows:

‖∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒩)‖2≥2​μ​[F​(𝐰(t),𝒩)−F​(𝐰∗,𝒩)].superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩22𝜇delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩𝐹superscript𝐰𝒩\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N})\|^{2}\geq 2\mu\left[F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*},\mathcal{N})\right]. (5)

II-A Weight Divergence in Conventional FedSGD

Since device selection is implemented in a federated learning algorithm using non-IID datasets, the data distribution of the selected devices may be different from the global data distribution, and therefore, the weight divergence issue may occur [15, 19]. That is, the divergence between the weights obtained from the considered federated learning framework and the desired weights obtained from centralized learning increases with training. To evaluate weight divergence, complete device selection is included as the baseline, where all devices are selected in each communication round. The updated of the true global model in this case is given by

𝐰T(t+1)=𝐰T(t)−λ​∇F​(𝐰T(t),𝒩),superscriptsubscript𝐰Tt1superscriptsubscript𝐰Tt𝜆∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰Tt𝒩\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(t+1)}}=\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(t)}}-\lambda\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N}), (6)

where

F​(𝐰T(t),𝒩)=∑n∈𝒩βn​fn​(𝐰T(t))∑n∈𝒩βn.𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰Tt𝒩subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰Ttsubscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝛽𝑛F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N})=\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\beta_{n}f_{n}(\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(t)}})}{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\beta_{n}}. (7)

Note that the complete device selection scheme can be treated as centralized learning, since in the considered federated learning algorithm, all local data is utilized for training and the number of local epochs is one. Based on the definition of the true global model, the following theorem can be obtained.

Theorem 1.

Defining the error caused by device selection as the difference in the global loss gradient between random device selection and complete device selection, i.e.,

𝐞(t)≜∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒮t)−∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒩),≜superscript𝐞t∇𝐹superscript𝐰tsubscript𝒮𝑡∇𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩\mathbf{e}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\triangleq\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{S}_{t})\!-\!\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N}), (8)

the weight divergence in the considered federated learning framework is bounded by:

‖𝐰(t+1)−𝐰T(t+1)‖≤(1+λ​L)t​‖𝐰(1)−𝐰T(1)‖+λ​‖∑i=1t𝐞(i)‖+λ2​L​∑j=1t−1(1+λ​L)j−1​‖∑i=1t−j𝐞(i)‖.normsuperscript𝐰t1superscriptsubscript𝐰Tt1superscript1𝜆𝐿𝑡normsuperscript𝐰1superscriptsubscript𝐰T1𝜆normsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡superscript𝐞𝑖superscript𝜆2𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑡1superscript1𝜆𝐿𝑗1normsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡𝑗superscript𝐞𝑖\left\|\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t+1)}}-\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(t+1)}}\right\|\leq(1\!+\!\lambda L)^{t}\left\|\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(1)}}\!-\!\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(1)}}\right\|\!+\!\lambda\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{t}\mathbf{e}^{(i)}\right\|\!+\!\lambda^{2}L\!\sum_{j=1}^{t-1}(1\!+\!\lambda L)^{j-1}\!\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{t-j}\!\mathbf{e}^{(i)}\right\|. (9)
Proof:

Refer to Appendix A. ∎

Theorem 1 indicates that in the considered federated learning framework, device selection leads to weight divergence, and this effect can be described as the error of the global loss gradient in each communication round. Based on Theorem 1, the following remarks can be obtained.

Remark 1.

In the considered federated learning algorithm, the weight divergence is mainly caused by two parts, including the difference between initial global models, i.e., ‖𝐰(1)−𝐰T(1)‖normsuperscript𝐰1superscriptsubscript𝐰T1\|\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(1)}}-\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(1)}}\|, and the accumulated error, i.e., ‖∑i𝐞(i)‖normsubscript𝑖superscript𝐞𝑖\|\sum_{i}\mathbf{e}^{(i)}\|.

Remark 2.

The impact of the accumulated error from previous rounds is amplified with training, since 1+λ​L>11𝜆𝐿11+\lambda L>1. That is, the impact of errors in the early stages of training plays a major role in weight divergence.

Remark 3.

When utilizing different initial global models, even if complete device selection is applied, i.e., the error is zero, large weight divergence may still be encountered.

It can be observed from Theorem 1 that the weight divergence can be mitigated by reducing ‖∑i=1t𝐞(i)‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡superscript𝐞𝑖\|\sum_{i=1}^{t}\mathbf{e}^{(i)}\|. To this end, conventional methods, such as importance sampling, focus on reducing ‖𝐞(t)‖normsuperscript𝐞t\|\mathbf{e}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\| in each communication round by bringing ∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒮t)∇𝐹superscript𝐰tsubscript𝒮𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{S}_{t}) closer to ∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒩)∇𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N}) [8, 26]. However, these methods need to analyze local gradients, which is impractical in the realistic scenario due to the high-complexity or privacy issues. Inspired by the fact that the errors are accumulated, this paper introduces a weighting factor222In this paper, the terms “weighting factor” and “weights” refer to the local gradient adjustment coefficient and neural network parameters, respectively. to scale the error of the current round according to the accumulated error from previous rounds, thereby reducing weight divergence. Specifically, by treating 𝐞(t)superscript𝐞t\mathbf{e}^{\mathrm{(t)}} and ∑i=1t−1𝐞(i)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡1superscript𝐞𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{t-1}\mathbf{e}^{(i)} as two vectors, if the elements in 𝐞(t)superscript𝐞t\mathbf{e}^{\mathrm{(t)}} are close to the corresponding elements in ∑i=1t−1𝐞(i)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡1superscript𝐞𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{t-1}\mathbf{e}^{(i)}, a small weighting factor is adopted to reduce these elements; otherwise, these elements are amplified. As a result, the accumulated error ∑i=1t−1𝐞(i)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡1superscript𝐞𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{t-1}\mathbf{e}^{(i)} can be compensated by using 𝐞(t)superscript𝐞t\mathbf{e}^{\mathrm{(t)}}, and the value of ‖∑i=1t𝐞(i)‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡superscript𝐞𝑖\|\sum_{i=1}^{t}\mathbf{e}^{(i)}\| can be reduced.

II-B Age-weighted FedSGD

Based on the definition of error in (8), weighting factor should be applied to ∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒮t)∇𝐹superscript𝐰tsubscript𝒮𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{S}_{t}), since ∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒩)∇𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N}) is unknown in practical training. In other words, the weighting factor should be designed according to the difference in device selection between communication rounds. In particular, in the considered system, some devices may need to wait several rounds before participating in the aggregation. In this case, AoI is introduced to record recent device selection status and generate weighting factors [27, 28]. For device n𝑛n, its AoI in round t𝑡t is defined as follows:

An(t)={1,ifn∈𝒮t−1,An(t−1)+1,ifn∉𝒮t−1.superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛tcases1if𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛t11if𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡1A_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1,&\quad\text{if}\quad n\in\mathcal{S}_{t-1},\\ A_{n}^{\mathrm{(t-1)}}+1,&\quad\text{if}\quad n\notin\mathcal{S}_{t-1}.\end{array}\right. (10)

The above equation indicates that if device n𝑛n is selected in last round, its AoI becomes 111; otherwise, it increases by 111. Based on this definition, the age-weighted FedSGD is proposed with the following weighting factor333The AoI based weighting factor presented in (11) is for simplicity. It is observed that learning performance is highly sensitive to AoI, and other expressions of the weighting factor may provide further improvements.:

ωn(t)=An(t)​|𝒮t|∑i∈𝒮tAi(t),superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑛tsuperscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛tsubscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑖t\omega_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}=\frac{A_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}A_{i}^{\mathrm{(t)}}}, (11)

where |𝒮t|subscript𝒮𝑡|\mathcal{S}_{t}| is included for normalization. At the server, the global model is updated based on the age-weighted local gradients, as follows:

𝐰(t+1)=𝐰(t)−λ​∇G​(𝐰(t),𝒮t),superscript𝐰t1superscript𝐰t𝜆∇𝐺superscript𝐰tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t+1)}}=\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}}-\lambda\nabla G(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{S}_{t}), (12)

where

G​(𝐰(t),𝒮t)=∑n∈𝒮tωn(t)​βn​fn​(𝐰(t))∑n∈𝒮tβn.𝐺superscript𝐰tsubscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑛tsubscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛superscript𝐰tsubscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛G(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{S}_{t})=\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\omega_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\beta_{n}f_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}})}{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\beta_{n}}. (13)

Note that the AoI of all devices can be counted at the server, and thus the proposed scheme does not require additional information transmission. Moreover, by including the AoI based weighting factor in the update of local models, the proposed approach can also be utilized in federated averaging (FedAvg), where the AoI of all devices can be transmitted together with the global model.

The performance of age-weighted FedSGD and conventional FedSGD is compared in Fig. 1, where weight divergence is calculated by ‖𝐰(t)−𝐰T(t)‖normsuperscript𝐰tsuperscriptsubscript𝐰Tt\|\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}}-\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\|. It can be observed that on non-IID datasets, weight divergence in conventional FedSGD increases with training, while age-weighted FedSGD can efficiently reduce weight divergence and control it to a certain level. Furthermore, it is worth pointing out that age-weighted FedSGD is still valid with IID data, although the weight divergence issue is not severe in this case.

II-C Performance Analysis

In this subsection, age-weighted FedSGD is analyzed for multi-class classification. Consider a C𝐶C-class classification problem with compact space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and label space 𝒴=𝒞𝒴𝒞\mathcal{Y}=\mathcal{C}, where 𝒞={1,2,…,C}𝒞12…𝐶\mathcal{C}=\{1,2,\dots,C\}. The data distribution of device n𝑛n is defined as follows:

Pn=[∑i=1βn𝟙yn,i=cβn|∀c∈𝒞],subscript𝑃𝑛delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝛽𝑛subscript1subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖𝑐subscript𝛽𝑛for-all𝑐𝒞P_{n}=\left[\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{\beta_{n}}\!\mathds{1}_{y_{n,i}=c}}{\beta_{n}}\bigg{|}\forall c\in\mathcal{C}\right], (14)

By adopting the cross-entropy loss, the local loss is given by

fn​(𝐰(t))subscript𝑓𝑛superscript𝐰t\displaystyle f_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}}) =𝔼𝐱,y∼Pn​[∑c∈𝒞𝟙y=c​log⁡fc​(𝒙,𝐰(t))]absentsubscript𝔼similar-to𝐱𝑦subscript𝑃𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝑐𝒞subscript1𝑦𝑐subscript𝑓𝑐𝒙superscript𝐰t\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{x},y\sim P_{n}}\!\left[\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}\mathds{1}_{y=c}\log f_{c}(\boldsymbol{x},\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}})\right]
=∑c∈𝒞Pn​(y=c)​𝔼𝒙|y=c​[log⁡fc​(𝒙,𝐰(t))],absentsubscript𝑐𝒞subscript𝑃𝑛𝑦𝑐subscript𝔼conditional𝒙𝑦𝑐delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑐𝒙superscript𝐰t\displaystyle=\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}P_{n}(y=c)\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}|y=c}\!\left[\log f_{c}(\boldsymbol{x},\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}})\right], (15)

where fc​(𝒙,𝐰(t))subscript𝑓𝑐𝒙superscript𝐰tf_{c}(\boldsymbol{x},\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}}) indicates the probability for class c𝑐c, and the sample (𝒙,y)𝒙𝑦(\boldsymbol{x},y) follows data distribution Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n}. In this case, by defining P𝒮tsubscript𝑃subscript𝒮𝑡P_{\mathcal{S}_{t}} and P𝒩subscript𝑃𝒩P_{\mathcal{N}} as the data distributions of the selected devices and all devices, i.e.,

P𝒮t=[∑n∈𝒮t∑i=1βn𝟙yn,i=c∑n∈𝒮tβn|∀c∈𝒞]=∑n∈𝒮tβn​Pn∑n∈𝒮tβn,subscript𝑃subscript𝒮𝑡delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝛽𝑛subscript1subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖𝑐subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛for-all𝑐𝒞subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛\displaystyle P_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!=\!\left[\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!\sum_{i=1}^{\beta_{n}}\!\mathds{1}_{y_{n,i}=c}}{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!\beta_{n}}\bigg{|}\forall c\in\mathcal{C}\right]\!=\!\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!\beta_{n}P_{n}}{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!\beta_{n}}, (16)

and

P𝒩=[∑n∈𝒩∑i=1βn𝟙yn,i=c∑n∈𝒩βn|∀c∈𝒞]=∑n∈𝒩βn​Pn∑n∈𝒩βn,subscript𝑃𝒩delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝛽𝑛subscript1subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖𝑐subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝛽𝑛for-all𝑐𝒞subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝛽𝑛P_{\mathcal{N}}\!=\!\left[\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\!\sum_{i=1}^{\beta_{n}}\!\mathds{1}_{y_{n,i}=c}}{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\!\beta_{n}}\bigg{|}\forall c\in\mathcal{C}\right]\!=\!\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\!\beta_{n}P_{n}}{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\!\beta_{n}}, (17)

the error in (8) can be expressed as

𝐞(t)=∑c∈𝒞[P𝒮t​(y=c)−P𝒩​(y=c)]​∇𝔼𝒙|y=c​[log⁡fc​(𝒙,𝐰(t))].superscript𝐞tsubscript𝑐𝒞delimited-[]subscript𝑃subscript𝒮𝑡𝑦𝑐subscript𝑃𝒩𝑦𝑐∇subscript𝔼conditional𝒙𝑦𝑐delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑐𝒙superscript𝐰t\mathbf{e}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\!=\!\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}}[P_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!(y\!=\!c)\!-\!\!P_{\mathcal{N}}(y\!=\!c)]\nabla\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}|y=c}\!\left[\log f_{c}(\boldsymbol{x},\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}})\right]. (18)

Based on this equation, the following remarks can be obtained.

Remark 4.

In the multi-class classification problem, the error caused by device selection is mainly determined by the distance between the data distribution of the selected devices P𝒮tsubscript𝑃subscript𝒮𝑡P_{\mathcal{S}_{t}} and the global data distribution P𝒩subscript𝑃𝒩P_{\mathcal{N}}, and this impact is affected by the gradient ∇𝔼𝐱|y=c​[log⁡fc​(𝐱,𝐰(t))]∇subscript𝔼conditional𝐱𝑦𝑐delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑐𝐱superscript𝐰t\nabla\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}|y=c}\left[\log f_{c}(\boldsymbol{x},\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}})\right].

Remark 5.

In the considered federated learning framework, if the data distribution of the selected devices is the same as the global data distribution, the weight divergence issue can be avoided.

According to Theorem 1, the impact of the error in any round is amplified with the increasing of communication rounds. That is, in the multi-class classification problem, the impact of data distributions caused by device selection is different due to the sequence of selection. Moreover, the data distribution P𝒮tsubscript𝑃subscript𝒮𝑡P_{\mathcal{S}_{t}} is determined by set 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t}, and the devices of this set may have different selection records. However, in conventional FedSGD, this difference is not reflected. In the proposed age-weighted FedSGD, the data distribution of set 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t} is given by

P𝒮tω=[∑n∈𝒮tωn(t)​∑i=1βn𝟙yn,i=c∑n∈𝒮tβn|∀c∈𝒞]=∑n∈𝒮tωn(t)​βn​Pn∑n∈𝒮tβn.superscriptsubscript𝑃subscript𝒮𝑡𝜔delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑛tsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝛽𝑛subscript1subscript𝑦𝑛𝑖𝑐subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛for-all𝑐𝒞subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑛tsubscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝛽𝑛P_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}^{\omega}\!=\!\left[\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!\omega_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\!\sum_{i=1}^{\beta_{n}}\!\mathds{1}_{y_{n,i}=c}}{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!\beta_{n}}\bigg{|}\forall c\in\mathcal{C}\right]\!=\!\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!\omega_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\!\beta_{n}P_{n}}{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\!\beta_{n}}. (19)

It can be seen that except data size βnsubscript𝛽𝑛\beta_{n}, another weighting factor ωn(t)superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑛t\omega_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}} is included to scale the influence from different devices based on the previous device selection results. Specifically, since the impact of 𝒮t−1subscript𝒮𝑡1\mathcal{S}_{t-1} is amplified in round t𝑡t, a big weighting factor should be included to the devices in 𝒩\𝒮t−1\𝒩subscript𝒮𝑡1\mathcal{N}\backslash\mathcal{S}_{t-1}. Due to the same reason, when any device in 𝒮t−1subscript𝒮𝑡1\mathcal{S}_{t-1} is selected in round t𝑡t, a small weighting factor should be included. Fig. 2 is included to explain age-weighted FedSGD, where 222 devices are selected in each communication round. Compared to conventional FedSGD, the global model obtained in round t+2𝑡2t+2, i.e., 𝐰(t+2)superscript𝐰t2\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t+2)}}, is closer to the local model of device C, since the gradients used in model updates are weighted according to the device selection result of round t+1𝑡1t+1. Due to the same reason, device D dominates the aggregation in round t+3𝑡3t+3. As a result, the distance between 𝐰(t+3)superscript𝐰t3\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t+3)}} and true global model 𝐰T(t+2)superscriptsubscript𝐰Tt2\mathbf{w}_{\mathrm{T}}^{\mathrm{(t+2)}} is reduced by utilizing age-weighted FedSGD.

With age-weighted FedSGD, the difference in global gradient between random device selection and complete device selection is given by

𝐠(t)≜∇G​(𝐰(t),𝒮t)−∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒩).≜superscript𝐠t∇𝐺superscript𝐰tsubscript𝒮𝑡∇𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩\mathbf{g}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\triangleq\nabla G(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{S}_{t})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N}). (20)

Since all devices are selected in complete device selection, An(t)=1,∀n,tsuperscriptsubscript𝐴𝑛t1for-all𝑛𝑡A_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}=1,\forall n,t always holds, and hence, the AoI based weighting factor satisfies ωn(t)=1superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑛t1\omega_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}=1. In this case, the following equation can be obtained:

∇G​(𝐰(t),𝒩)=∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒩).∇𝐺superscript𝐰t𝒩∇𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩\nabla G(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N})=\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N}). (21)

The above equation indicates that age-weighted FedSGD can be utilized for complete device selection without any impact. Based on (20) and (21), the expected convergence rate of age-weighted FedSGD can be obtained.

Theorem 2.

With age-weighted FedSGD, the expected reduction of global loss in round t𝑡t is bounded by

𝔼​[F​(𝐰(t+1),𝒩)−F​(𝐰∗)]≤(1−μL)t​𝔼​[F​(𝐰(1),𝒩)−F​(𝐰∗)]+12​L​∑i=1t(1−μL)t−i​𝔼​[‖𝐠(i)‖2],𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰t1𝒩𝐹superscript𝐰superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰1𝒩𝐹superscript𝐰12𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝐠𝑖2\mathbb{E}\!\left[F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t+1)}},\mathcal{N})\!-\!F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\right]\!\leq\!\left(\!1\!\!-\!\!\frac{\mu}{L}\!\right)^{t}\!\!\mathbb{E}\!\left[\!F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(1)}},\mathcal{N})\!-\!\!F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\!\right]\!\!+\!\!\frac{1}{2L}\!\sum_{i=1}^{t}\!\left(\!1\!\!-\!\!\frac{\mu}{L}\!\right)^{t-i}\!\!\mathbb{E}\!\left[\!\|\mathbf{g}^{(i)}\|^{2}\!\right],\!\!\! (22)

where

𝔼​[‖𝐠(t)‖2]=(1−|𝒮t|N)​∑n∈𝒩βn2​‖ωn(t)​∇fn​(𝐰(t))−∇F​(𝐰(t),𝒩)‖2|𝒮t|​(N−1)​(1N​∑n∈𝒩βn)2.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝐠t21subscript𝒮𝑡𝑁subscript𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑛2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑛t∇subscript𝑓𝑛superscript𝐰t∇𝐹superscript𝐰t𝒩2subscript𝒮𝑡𝑁1superscript1𝑁subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝛽𝑛2\mathbb{E}\!\left[\|\mathbf{g}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\|^{2}\right]=\left(\!1\!-\!\frac{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}{N}\right)\!\!\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\!\beta_{n}^{2}\left\|\omega_{n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\nabla f_{n}(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}})\!-\!\!\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{\mathrm{(t)}},\mathcal{N})\right\|^{2}}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|(N\!-\!1)(\frac{1}{N}\!\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\!\beta_{n})^{2}}. (23)
Proof:

Refer to Appendix B. ∎

Theorem 2 indicates that the convergence rate of the considered federated learning algorithm can be improved by increasing the number of selected devices, i.e., |𝒮t|subscript𝒮𝑡|\mathcal{S}_{t}|. On the other hand, the weight divergence issue will be more severe if some devices are unavailable, since the data distribution in this case is different from the global data distribution. As a result, in order to improve device availability, the optimization of the computation and transmission stages needs to be considered.

II-D Local Training and Transmission

For any selected device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k, it trains the global model based on all local samples, and hence, the computing time can be expressed as follows:

Tk,ncp=μ​βnτk,n​Cn,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cp𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛T_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cp}}=\frac{\mu\beta_{n}}{\tau_{k,n}C_{n}}, (24)

where μ𝜇\mu is the required number of cycles to train each sample, τk,nsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛\tau_{k,n} is the computing resource allocation coefficient, and Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n} is the computational capacity of device n𝑛n. According to [21, 19], the corresponding energy consumption for local training is given by

Ek,ncp=κ​μ​βn​(τk,n​Cn)2,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cp𝜅𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛2E_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cp}}=\kappa\mu\beta_{n}(\tau_{k,n}C_{n})^{2}, (25)

where κ𝜅\kappa is the power consumption coefficient of each central processing unit (CPU) cycle. After local training, the local gradient is sent to the server through the assigned sub-channel at the following data rate:

Rk,n=B​log2⁡(1+αk,n​Pn​|hk,n|2),subscript𝑅𝑘𝑛𝐵subscript21subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2R_{k,n}=B\log_{2}(1+\alpha_{k,n}P_{n}|h_{k,n}|^{2}), (26)

where B𝐵B is the allocated bandwidth of each sub-channel, αk,nsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑛\alpha_{k,n} is the power allocation coefficient, Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n} is the maximum transmit power, |hk,n|2=η​|gn|2​dn−a​σ−2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑛𝑎superscript𝜎2|h_{k,n}|^{2}=\eta|g_{n}|^{2}d_{n}^{-a}\sigma^{-2} is the normalized channel gain, η𝜂\eta is the frequency dependent factor, gnsubscript𝑔𝑛g_{n} is the small-scale fading coefficient, dnsubscript𝑑𝑛d_{n} is the distance between device n𝑛n and the server, α𝛼\alpha is the path loss exponent, and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the noise power. The communication time of device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k can be expressed as follows:

Tk,ncm=DRk,n,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cm𝐷subscript𝑅𝑘𝑛T_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cm}}=\frac{D}{R_{k,n}}, (27)

where D𝐷D is the size of the local gradient for each device. The energy consumption for transmission is given by

Ek,ncm=αk,n​Pn​Tk,ncm.superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cmsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cmE_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cm}}=\alpha_{k,n}P_{n}T_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cm}}. (28)

III Problem Formulation

In order to improve learning performance by increasing device availability, an energy consumption minimization problem is formulated under the maximum time consumption constraint, as shown in follows:

min𝝉,𝜶,𝝍subscript𝝉𝜶𝝍\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{\tau},\boldsymbol{\alpha},\boldsymbol{\psi}}\quad ∑n∈𝒮t∑k∈𝒦ψk,n​(Ek,ncp+Ek,ncm)subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝜓𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cm\displaystyle\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\psi_{k,n}(E_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cp}}+E_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cm}}) (29a)
s.t. Tk,ncp+Tk,ncm≤Tnmax,∀k∈𝒦,∀n∈𝒮t,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cpsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑛cmsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛maxformulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡\displaystyle T_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cp}}+T_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cm}}\leq T_{n}^{\mathrm{max}},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\forall n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}, (29b)
τk,n∈[0,1],∀k∈𝒦,∀n∈𝒮t,formulae-sequencesubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛01formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡\displaystyle\tau_{k,n}\in[0,1],\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\forall n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}, (29c)
αk,n∈[0,1],∀k∈𝒦,∀n∈𝒮t,formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘𝑛01formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡\displaystyle\alpha_{k,n}\in[0,1],\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\forall n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}, (29d)
ψk,n(t)∈{0,1},∀k∈𝒦,∀n∈𝒮t,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛t01formulae-sequencefor-all𝑘𝒦for-all𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡\displaystyle\psi_{k,n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\in\{0,1\},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\forall n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}, (29e)
∑n∈𝒮tψk,n(t)∈{0,1},∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛t01for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\psi_{k,n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\in\{0,1\},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (29f)
∑k∈𝒦ψk,n(t)∈{0,1},∀n∈𝒮t,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑘𝑛t01for-all𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\psi_{k,n}^{\mathrm{(t)}}\in\{0,1\},\forall n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}, (29g)

where 𝝉𝝉\boldsymbol{\tau}, 𝜶𝜶\boldsymbol{\alpha}, and 𝝍𝝍\boldsymbol{\psi} are the sets of all computing resource allocation coefficients, power allocation coefficients, and sub-channel assignment indicators, respectively. In constraint (29b), Tnmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛maxT_{n}^{\mathrm{max}} denotes the maximum time consumption of each communication round. Constraints (29c) and (29d) indicate that computing resource allocation coefficients and power allocation coefficients range from 00 to 111. Constraints (29e), (29f) and (29g) represent that the sub-channel assignment indicator is a binary variable, any sub-channel can be occupied by at most one device, and any device can be assigned to at most one sub-channel, respectively. In particular, in problem (29), resource allocation and sub-channel assignment are performed with the given set of selected devices.

Due to the fact that the formulated problem is a mixed integer linear programming problem, it is decoupled into two sub-problems and solved iteratively. With the fixed sub-channel assignment, the resource allocation problem can be presented as follows:

min𝝉,𝜶subscript𝝉𝜶\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{\tau},\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\quad ∑n∈𝒮t∑k∈𝒦Ek,ncp+Ek,ncmsubscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cm\displaystyle\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}E_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cp}}+E_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cm}} (30a)
s.t. (29b), (29c), and (29d).(29b), (29c), and (29d)\displaystyle\text{(\ref{problem}b), (\ref{problem}c), and (\ref{problem}d)}.

By removing the constraints related to resource allocation, the sub-channel assignment problem is shown in follows:

min𝝍subscript𝝍\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{\psi}}\quad ∑n∈𝒮t∑k∈𝒦ψk,n​(Ek,ncp+Ek,ncm)subscript𝑛subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝜓𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cm\displaystyle\sum_{n\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\psi_{k,n}(E_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cp}}+E_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cm}}) (31a)
s.t. (29e), (29f), and (29g).(29e), (29f), and (29g)\displaystyle\text{(\ref{problem}e), (\ref{problem}f), and (\ref{problem}g)}.

IV Joint Optimization of Computational Resource Allocation and Power Allocation

Since the adjustment of resource allocation coefficients for any device cannot affect other devices, the resource allocation problem in (30) is divided into K𝐾K sub-problems and solved independently. The resource allocation problem for device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k is given by

minτk,n,αk,nsubscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛\displaystyle\min_{\tau_{k,n},\alpha_{k,n}}\quad\!\!\!\!\! κ​μ​βn​(τk,n​Cn)2+αk,n​Pn​DB​log2⁡(1+αk,n​Pn​|hk,n|2)𝜅𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛2subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛𝐷𝐵subscript21subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle\kappa\mu\beta_{n}(\tau_{k,n}C_{n})^{2}\!+\!\frac{\alpha_{k,n}P_{n}D}{B\log_{2}(1\!+\!\alpha_{k,n}P_{n}|h_{k,n}|^{2})} (32a)
s.t. μ​βnτk,n​Cn+DB​log2⁡(1+αk,n​Pn​|hk,n|2)≤Tnmax,𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛𝐷𝐵subscript21subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛max\displaystyle\!\frac{\mu\beta_{n}}{\tau_{k,n}C_{n}}\!+\!\frac{D}{B\log_{2}(1\!+\!\alpha_{k,n}P_{n}|h_{k,n}|^{2})}\leq T_{n}^{\mathrm{max}},\!\! (32b)
τk,n∈[0,1],subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛01\displaystyle\tau_{k,n}\in[0,1], (32c)
αk,n∈[0,1].subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛01\displaystyle\alpha_{k,n}\in[0,1]. (32d)

Note that the above problem is infeasible if any constraint is not satisfied. Hence, the following remark can be drawn.

Remark 6.

For any device n𝑛n assigned to sub-channel k𝑘k, its local gradient cannot be transmitted if

μ​βnCn+DB​log2⁡(1+Pn​|hk,n|2)>Tnmax.𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛𝐷𝐵subscript21subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛max\frac{\mu\beta_{n}}{C_{n}}+\frac{D}{B\log_{2}(1+P_{n}|h_{k,n}|^{2})}>T_{n}^{\mathrm{max}}. (33)

That is, the selected devices may not be able to transmit local gradients to the server with the given time limitation, even if all resources are utilized. On the other hand, if this condition does not hold, the training and transmission tasks can alway be completed, which means τk,n>0subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛0\tau_{k,n}>0 and αk,n>0subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛0\alpha_{k,n}>0. Therefore, x1subscript𝑥1x_{1} and x2subscript𝑥2x_{2} are introduced to replace the optimization variables, where x1=1/τk,nsubscript𝑥11subscript𝜏𝑘𝑛x_{1}=1/\tau_{k,n} and x2=1/[B​log2⁡(1+αk,n​Pn​|hk,n|2)]subscript𝑥21delimited-[]𝐵subscript21subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2x_{2}=1/[B\log_{2}(1+\alpha_{k,n}P_{n}|h_{k,n}|^{2})]. Problem (32) can be equivalently transformed as follows:

min𝐱subscript𝐱\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{x}}\quad κ​μ​βn​Cn2x12+x2​(21x2​B−1)​D|hk,n|2,𝜅𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑥12subscript𝑥2superscript21subscript𝑥2𝐵1𝐷superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle\frac{\kappa\mu\beta_{n}C_{n}^{2}}{x_{1}^{2}}\!+\!x_{2}\frac{(2^{\frac{1}{x_{2}B}}-1)D}{|h_{k,n}|^{2}}, (34a)
s.t. μ​βn​Cn−1​x1+D​x2≤Tnmax,𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛1subscript𝑥1𝐷subscript𝑥2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛max\displaystyle\mu\beta_{n}C_{n}^{-1}x_{1}+Dx_{2}\leq T_{n}^{\mathrm{max}}, (34b)
x1≥1,subscript𝑥11\displaystyle x_{1}\geq 1, (34c)
x2≥1B​log2⁡(1+Pn​|hk,n|2),subscript𝑥21𝐵subscript21subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2\displaystyle x_{2}\geq\frac{1}{B\log_{2}(1+P_{n}|h_{k,n}|^{2})}, (34d)

where 𝐱={x1,x2}𝐱subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2\mathbf{x}=\{x_{1},x_{2}\}. It can be proved that the above problem is convex and satisfies Slater’s condition, and hence, KKT conditions are utilized to derive the optimal solution [29]. By introducing the Lagrangian multiplier λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} for the inequality constraints, the Lagrangian function is given by

L​(𝐱)𝐿𝐱\displaystyle\!L(\mathbf{x}) =κ​μ​βn​Cn2x12+x2​(21x2​B−1)​D|hk,n|2+λ1​(μ​βnCn​x1+D​x2−Tnmax)absent𝜅𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑥12subscript𝑥2superscript21subscript𝑥2𝐵1𝐷superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2subscript𝜆1𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝑥1𝐷subscript𝑥2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛max\displaystyle\!=\!\frac{\kappa\mu\beta_{n}C_{n}^{2}}{x_{1}^{2}}\!+\!x_{2}\frac{(2^{\frac{1}{x_{2}B}}\!-\!1)D}{|h_{k,n}|^{2}}\!+\!\lambda_{1}\!\!\left(\!\frac{\mu\beta_{n}}{C_{n}}x_{1}\!\!+\!\!Dx_{2}\!\!-\!T_{n}^{\mathrm{max}}\!\!\right)
+λ2​(1−x1)+λ3​[1B​log2⁡(1+Pn​|hk,n|2)−x2].subscript𝜆21subscript𝑥1subscript𝜆3delimited-[]1𝐵subscript21subscript𝑃𝑛superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑛2subscript𝑥2\displaystyle\quad\!+\!\lambda_{2}(1\!-\!x_{1})\!+\!\lambda_{3}\!\!\left[\frac{1}{B\log_{2}(1\!\!+\!\!P_{n}|h_{k,n}|^{2})}\!-\!x_{2}\right]. (35)

and the formulated problem in (30) is jointly solved.

V Matching based Sub-Channel Assignment

In this section, the formulated sub-channel assignment problem in (31) is solved with the given resource allocation solutions. Specifically, the optimal resource allocation for all devices assigned to all sub-channels can be obtained in Section IV, and therefore, this solution is treated as a preference list to construct a matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm. Note that some combinations of devices and sub-channels may not be feasible due to inability to satisfy the maximum time consumption constraint, and the proposed algorithm may tend to assign devices to the corresponding infeasible sub-channels to achieve lower energy consumption. In order to avoid this case, a large value is assigned as the energy consumption of these infeasible combinations, and any combination with this energy consumption will be removed from the final matching.

V-A Design of Matching based Algorithm

At this stage, with the preference list setting, all devices in 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t} can be assigned to sub-channels, and thus problem (31) can be considered as a one-to-one matching ΨΨ\Psi from 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t} to 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}, where 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t} and 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} are two disjoint sets with the same size. In the resource allocation problem, it is indicated that the energy consumption of any device n𝑛n or sub-channel k𝑘k in matching ΨΨ\Psi is independent of other players, and therefore, the utility of any player can be defined as follows:

Ui​(Ψ)=Ek,ncp+Ek,ncm,∀i∈{n,k}.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑈𝑖Ψsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑛cmfor-all𝑖𝑛𝑘U_{i}(\Psi)=E_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cp}}+E_{k,n}^{\mathrm{cm}},\forall i\in\{n,k\}. (42)

Due to the fact that the device and sub-channel in a combination have the same utility, the intent of sub-channels can be omitted. Moreover, since each device is assigned to one sub-channel and each sub-channel is occupied by one device, if a device tends to establish a new matching, it needs to exchange with another device instead of joining the combination directly. That is, the considered matching is a swap matching, defined as follows:

Definition 1.

From matching ΨΨ\Psi with Ψ​(n)=kΨ𝑛𝑘\Psi(n)=k and Ψ​(n′)=k′Ψsuperscript𝑛′superscript𝑘′\Psi(n^{\prime})=k^{\prime}, a swap matching Ψnn′superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑛superscript𝑛′\Psi_{n}^{n^{\prime}} represents an exchange of devices n𝑛n and n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime}, i.e.,

Ψnn′=Ψ\{{k,n},{k′,n′}}∪{{k,n′},{k′,n}}.superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑛superscript𝑛′\Ψ𝑘𝑛superscript𝑘′superscript𝑛′𝑘superscript𝑛′superscript𝑘′𝑛\Psi_{n}^{n^{\prime}}=\Psi\backslash\{\{k,n\},\{k^{\prime},n^{\prime}\}\}\cup\{\{k,n^{\prime}\},\{k^{\prime},n\}\}. (43)

As defined above, a swap matching means that two devices exchange their assigned sub-channels. Note that the motivation to form a swap matching is the reduction in energy consumption, which can be presented as follows:

Ψ⪯iΨnn′⇔Ui​(Ψ)≤Ui​(Ψnn′),∀i∈{n,n′},⇔subscriptprecedes-or-equals𝑖ΨsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑛superscript𝑛′formulae-sequencesubscript𝑈𝑖Ψsubscript𝑈𝑖superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑛superscript𝑛′for-all𝑖𝑛superscript𝑛′\Psi\preceq_{i}\Psi_{n}^{n^{\prime}}\Leftrightarrow U_{i}(\Psi)\leq U_{i}(\Psi_{n}^{n^{\prime}}),\forall i\in\{n,n^{\prime}\}, (44)

where Ψ⪯iΨnn′subscriptprecedes-or-equals𝑖ΨsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑛superscript𝑛′\Psi\preceq_{i}\Psi_{n}^{n^{\prime}} indicates device i𝑖i prefers Ψnn′superscriptsubscriptΨ𝑛superscript𝑛′\Psi_{n}^{n^{\prime}} to ΨΨ\Psi. Moreover, symbol ≺isubscriptprecedes𝑖\prec_{i} is also introduced to represent the strict preference of device i𝑖i. The swap matching should be approved by all involved players, in which the utility of any player increases or remains unchanged. In this case, devices n𝑛n and n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} becomes a swap-blocking pair (n,n′)𝑛superscript𝑛′(n,n^{\prime}), defined as follows:

Definition 2.

(n,n′)𝑛superscript𝑛′(n,n^{\prime}) is a swap-blocking pair if and only if Ψ≺iΨnn′,∃i∈{n,n′}formulae-sequencesubscriptprecedes𝑖ΨsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑛superscript𝑛′𝑖𝑛superscript𝑛′\Psi\prec_{i}\Psi_{n}^{n^{\prime}},\exists i\in\{n,n^{\prime}\} and Ψ⪯iΨnn′,∀i∈{n,n′}formulae-sequencesubscriptprecedes-or-equals𝑖ΨsuperscriptsubscriptΨ𝑛superscript𝑛′for-all𝑖𝑛superscript𝑛′\Psi\preceq_{i}\Psi_{n}^{n^{\prime}},\forall i\in\{n,n^{\prime}\}.

Based on the definition of the swap-blocking pair, a matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm is presented in Algorithm 1. In this algorithm, an initial matching is firstly obtained by randomly assigning all devices into all sub-channels. Afterwards, each device in turn operates on the remaining devices in order to find the swap-blocking pair. If any two devices can form a swap-blocking pair, their sub-channels are exchanged and the new matching is recorded. This algorithm is repeated until no new swap-blocking pair can be found in a complete cycle. Based on the finial matching provided by Algorithm 1, the solution of sub-channel assignment problem (31) can be obtained by removing all infeasible combinations.

V-B Properties Analysis

In this subsection, the properties of the proposed matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm, including complexity, convergence, and stability, are analyzed.

V-B1 Complexity

The computational complexity of the proposed algorithm is 𝒪​(C​K2)𝒪𝐶superscript𝐾2\mathcal{O}(CK^{2}), where C𝐶C is the number of cycles. Specifically, during a complete cycle of the main loop, each device needs to test the viability of creating swap-blocking pairs with all other devices, and hence, for all K𝐾K devices, K​(K−1)𝐾𝐾1K(K-1) times of calculations should be performed. With the given number of cycles C𝐶C, the computational complexity can be expressed as C​K​(K−1)𝐶𝐾𝐾1CK(K-1).

V-B2 Convergence

From any initial matching, the proposed algorithm is guaranteed to converge to a final matching without swap-blocking pairs. It can be observed from Algorithm 1 that the matching is transformed due to the construction of swap-blocking pairs. Suppose ΨasubscriptΨ𝑎\Psi_{a} and ΨbsubscriptΨ𝑏\Psi_{b} are two adjacent matching, where a≠b𝑎𝑏a\neq b, then there exists a swap-blocking pair in the transformation from ΨasubscriptΨ𝑎\Psi_{a} to ΨbsubscriptΨ𝑏\Psi_{b}. Based on the definition of a swap-blocking pair, it indicates that the utility of at least one device is strictly reduced while the utility of the other device is not increased. Moreover, for the devices that are not involved, their utility remains the same. As a result, the sum utility, or sum energy consumption, is strictly decreased with this transformation. With the given devices and sub-channels, there is a lower bound on the energy consumption, and therefore, the proposed algorithm can always converge to a final matching.

V-B3 Stability

The proposed matching based sub-channel assignment algorithm is able to provide a two-side exchange stable solution, which is defined as follows:

Definition 3.

A matching is two-side exchange stable if and only if no swap-blocking pair can be formed.

According to the above definition, the final matching obtained by the proposed algorithm is alway two-side exchange stable, since the convergence analysis proves that there are no swap-blocking pairs in the final matching.

VI Simulation Results

The simulation results are presented to demonstrate the performance of age-weighted FedSGD and proposed solutions. In this simulation, the devices are randomly deployed in a disc with radius R𝑅R, while the server is located in the center. The learning rate λ𝜆\lambda is 0.010.010.01, bandwidth B𝐵B is 111 MHz, noise power σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is −174174-174 dBm, path loss exponent a𝑎a is 3.763.763.76, power consumption coefficient κ𝜅\kappa is 10−29superscript102910^{-29}, and cycles coefficient μ𝜇\mu is 106superscript10610^{6}. To evaluate the learning performance, MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100 datasets are adopted with an SGD optimizer. For MNIST digit recognition tasks, a simple neural network is built with a 128128128-neuron ReLu hidden layer and a softmax output layer. For CIFAR-10 image classification tasks, a neural network is constructed by stacking a 323232-filter 4×4444\times 4 2D convolution (Conv2D) layers, a 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layer, a 128128128-neuron ReLu hidden layer and a softmax output layer. For CIFAR-100 image classification tasks,, the neural network is constructed with a 128128128-filter 4×4444\times 4 Conv2D layers, a 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layer, a 256256256-neuron ReLu hidden layer and a softmax output layer. To compare the performance of the proposed KKT based resource allocation (denoted by KRA) and matching based sub-channel assignment (denoted by MSA), fixed resource allocation (denoted by FRA) and random sub-channel assignment (denoted by RSA) are respectively included as the baseline, where resource allocation coefficients are set as τk,n=αk,n=0.5,∀k,nformulae-sequencesubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛0.5for-all𝑘𝑛\tau_{k,n}=\alpha_{k,n}=0.5,\forall k,n with FRA 1, and τk,n=αk,n=1,∀k,nformulae-sequencesubscript𝜏𝑘𝑛subscript𝛼𝑘𝑛1for-all𝑘𝑛\tau_{k,n}=\alpha_{k,n}=1,\forall k,n with FRA 2.

In Fig. 3, the MNIST digit recognition task with unbalanced non-IID data is adopted, where 900090009000 training samples are randomly distributed to all devices, and the samples of each device belong to 111 or 222 classes. It demonstrates that with the same device selection results, the proposed age-weighted FedSGD is able to outperform conventional FedSGD with any sub-channel assignment and resource allocation schemes. Compared to RSA and FRA, MSA and KRA can also improve the performance of federated learning. Moreover, since the number of selected devices in each communication round is obviously reduced with FRA, there exist a large gap between FRA and KRA in achievable test accuracy.

The CIFAR-10 image classification task is employed in Fig. 4, in which each device has 500050005000 samples with the unique label. In this figure, the average number of selected devices is 2.45412.45412.4541 and 3.73923.73923.7392 for RSA and MSA, respectively. In other words, by utilizing the proposed sub-channel assignment strategy, the device availability is increased by 52%percent5252\%. As a result, for both age-weight FedSGD and conventional FedSGD, the learning performance is improved with the proposed solution. Moreover, it can be found from Fig. 4 that with the same device selection results, age-weighted FedSGD can achieve faster convergence rate compared to conventional FedSGD.

The balanced CIFAR-100 dataset is adopted in Fig. 5, in which each device has 100010001000 222-class samples. Due to the fact that the Non-IID degree in this figure is decreased compared to that in Fig. 3 and Fig. 4, the improvement of age-weighted FedSGD with MSA is not significant, but it can still improve the learning performance, especially in the later stage of training. With RSA, the advantage of age-weighted FedSGD is obvious, and this is because the number of selected devices in each round is significantly reduced. Specifically, under this parameter setting, the device selection probabilities are 97.96%percent97.9697.96\% and 65.45%percent65.4565.45\% with MSA and RSA, respectively.

The performance of the proposed solutions is shown in Fig. 6 to Fig. 8, where the maximum time consumption, radius, maximum transmit power, and computational capacity are respectively included to show its impact on the average energy consumption and the number of selected devices. It can be observed that compared to FRA 2, the obtained KKT based resource allocation solution can guarantee the same number of selected devices and achieve less energy consumption. Compared to FRA 1, KRA can reduce energy consumption and increase the number of selected devices, which explains the improved learning performance in Fig. 3 to Fig. 5. Moreover, Fig. 6 indicates that there is a trade-off between energy consumption and the number of selected devices. Specifically, when the maximum time consumption increases from 222 s to 444 s, the energy consumption is raised in order to significantly increase the number of selected devices, from 0.40.40.4 to 333. When the maximum time consumption is greater than 444 s, the number of selected devices can be slowly increased, but the average energy consumption is reduced. In Fig. 7, the increase in radius can be regarded as the deterioration of channel conditions, and then it can be observed that there is an upper boundary in energy consumption. That is, when the radius is greater than 250250250 m, the average energy consumption is maintained at a fixed level even though the number of selected devices continues to decrease. Similarly, an upper bound in the number of selected devices can be found in Fig. 8. When the maximum transmit power is equal to 303030 dBm, the maximum device availability is achieve by all schemes, and the proposed solutions still consume minimum energy. Compared to the maximum transmit power, the impact of computational capacity is not significant, but the overall trend is the same, i.e., the energy consumption and the number of selected devices increase monotonically, as shown in Fig. 9.

The convergence of the proposed sub-channel assignment algorithm is demonstrated in Fig. 10, where exhaustive search is included as the benchmark. In this figure, the exhaustive search is set up to find the combination that maximizes the number of selected devices while guaranteeing a low level of average energy consumption. Therefore, although the average energy consumption obtained by the exhaustive search is slightly larger than that of the proposed matching based algorithm, the number of selected devices is significantly increased. It can be observed that the proposed sub-channel assignment algorithm can achieve approximately 92%percent9292\% performance of the global optimum within 444 iterations. Compared to exhaustive search with complexity 𝒪​(K!)𝒪𝐾\mathcal{O}(K!), it can be considered as a low complexity sub-optimal algorithm. Furthermore, the figure verifies the properties of the proposed algorithm, including convergence and stability.

VII Conclusions

This paper investigates a wireless federated learning framework on non-IID datasets, where random device selection is exploited due to the limited number of sub-channels. By exploring the issue of conventional FedSGD in weight divergence, age-weighted FedSGD is designed to adjust the proportion of local gradients according to the previous state of devices. To further improve the learning performance, an energy consumption minimization problem is formulated, where the resource allocation solution and the sub-channel assignment algorithm are developed based on KKT conditions and matching theory, respectively. The superiority of designed age-weighted FedSGD and the effectiveness of the proposed resource allocation and sub-channel assignment strategies are demonstrated in the simulation results.

where υ1subscript𝜐1\upsilon_{1} is defined in (36). If λ1=0subscript𝜆10\lambda_{1}=0, the following equation can be obtained from (60a):

−2​κ​μ​βn​Cn2​(x1∗)−3=λ2.2𝜅𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥13subscript𝜆2-2\kappa\mu\beta_{n}C_{n}^{2}(x_{1}^{*})^{-3}=\lambda_{2}. (62)

Since λ2≥0subscript𝜆20\lambda_{2}\geq 0, the above function conflicts with (61b), and hence, λ1>0subscript𝜆10\lambda_{1}>0 always holds. Therefore, it can be obtained from (61d) that the following equation is always satisfied:

μ​βn​Cn−1​x1∗+D​x2∗−Tnmax=0.𝜇subscript𝛽𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑥1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑥2superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛max0\mu\beta_{n}C_{n}^{-1}x_{1}^{*}+Dx_{2}^{*}-T_{n}^{\mathrm{max}}=0. (63)

At this stage, based on the different values of λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} and λ3subscript𝜆3\lambda_{3}, four cases need to be discussed.

1) If λ2>0subscript𝜆20\lambda_{2}>0 and λ3>0subscript𝜆30\lambda_{3}>0, x1∗=1superscriptsubscript𝑥11x_{1}^{*}=1 and x2∗=υ1superscriptsubscript𝑥2subscript𝜐1x_{2}^{*}=\upsilon_{1} can be obtained from (61e) and (61f), respectively. In this case, the following condition can be derived from (63):

and the following inequality can be obtained:
